events.name: FREE Web Development Training (ASP.NET MVC using .NET Core 1.0)
events.description: Hi All, Want to know more about ASP.NET MVC? Still confused and trying to understand MVC? JOIN THIS FREE TRAINING! As requested by numerous members, we will be having our second FREE Training! This time it will be on Web App Development using ASP.NET MVC Core 1.0. The training is for novices to professionals who would like to know more about .NET's latest technology. We are limiting the seats to 80 only, please register early to avoid disappointment.  This workshop is a full stack development training consisting of concept, design, coding, GitHub source control, continuous deployment and hosting. We will be also including content on how to host in Nano Server! We will be using the free training tools and open source related materials; mainly Visual Studio 2015 Community (not the Visual Studio Code). Don't forget to install it!  So, what do you need to bring for this training: * BYOD (bring your own devices!). * Make sure you have Visual Studio 2015 Update 2 Community Edition or Enterprise installed. You can download the community edition from Visual Studio 2015 page. When installing, do make sure you have checked C# components. * Install the .NET Core 1.0 RC2 from this link. If you are unsure on this, we can do it together during the training. TRAINERS* Riza Marhaban (Development part)* Louis Leong (DevOps expert) TAKEAWAYs from the training* Able to understand ASP.NET.* Able to understand what is MVC.* Know how to use GitHub.* Know how to deploy and maintain web apps.* Know what it takes to become a web app developer LUNCH* Provided for participants only. THANK YOU* Microsoft for sponsoring the venue and food. See you on JUNE 21st. And thank you very much for your support to this community. Do feel free to ask any questions and we will get back to you asap. Regards,MingOrganizer
events.location: Microsoft Auditorium (Singapore), One Marina Boulevard, Level 21 Auditorium, Singapore 018989

events.name: Humla Workshop -  The exploit research series - Part 3
events.description:
We are pleased to inform Humla Hands-On workshop on Exploit ResearchPart 3 by Srinivasa Rao Kotipalli Please note, this event is a FREE hands-on workshop, we can accommodate only few selected participants. If you get selected, you will receive email from humla champion by 19th June 2016. *** We are looking for more speakers to contribute to this series. Please get in touch if you are interested.  Selection Criteria: Selection (15-20 persons only) will be based on the following two criteria: 1. Contribution to the community. Speakers, humla, bachav champions, core team, volunteers  and venue hosts will get priority to the workshop.  2. Passion towards Information security + the attendance in previous meet ups.   If you are new to the community, selection will be based on the answers to the survey questions asked during the registration process. Please answer these questions carefully. Agenda:  Every day numerous software exploits are being disclosed, some openly and some via vendors. The Exploit research, series of workshops will cover how to identify software vulnerabilities, what techniques are used by attackers to exploit software flaws and how we can find and fix bugs before bad guys do.   The aim of these workshops is to teach participant about the following topics 1.  How to find security issues using static code analysis and fuzzing. 2.  Stack/SEH/Heap Overflows, egg hunting and custom shell code creation.   3.  ASLR Bypass and other security bypasses. 4.  Porting the exploits to Metasploit 5.  How to fix security issues. 


In the third part of this series, we will cover the following of exploit research, 1.  SEH based overflows 2.  Jumping to shellcode in 6 different ways and multi stage payloads. 3.  Egg hunting for limited buffer space. 


Pre-requisites: Basics of Assembly Language and should be comfortable working with command line.   Don’t know assembly? Watch these videos - https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL96AB65DFCE02EE3E  Who should attend ? :  Anyone who is interested in low level exploitation, reverse engineering and malware analysis. What should I bring with me? : Hardware: Laptop which can run two VMs simultaneously with at least 4 GB RAM and minimum 30 GB hard disk free space. Software:   VMware Player Installed with Windows Vista and Kali VM (32 bit). Immunity debugger (free version) installed on the windows Vista VM. You also need to install python for immunity. More instructions will be sent via email.  


Editor: Notepad++ (preferred) or any editor of your choice installed in windows Vista VM ( VIM or emacs anyone ;) ) 


Null humla champion: Srinivasa Rao Kotipalli is an OSCP (@srini0x00) works as a Security Engineer. Srinivas has extensive hands-on experience performing Web Application, Infrastructure and Mobile Security Assessments. He blogs at www.androidpentesting.com Please reach out to humla champion, if you have any questions regarding the event.
events.group_name: Null Singapore - The Open Security Community

events.name: June Meetup (RDRC Edition)
events.description:
Hi folks! We look forward to having you join us for our June meetup,on the 21st of June at 7pm. This is the special RedDotRubyConf edition before theconference on 23 June!  (P.S. Have you bought your tickets yet http://www.reddotrubyconf.com/?) Venue TBC. Ping us (Winston or Guo Xiang) if your company would like tosponsor or if you'd like to do a 10-15min talk or 5 Ruby Tips. -------------- 

1. The making of Twemoji Gem and Announcement beyond SG50 ~ @JuanitoFatas from @jollygoodcode 2. "5 Random Ruby Tips" ~ @hanmd82 from @ruckuswireless 3. Announcements * Hot Picks- This is a 5-10 minutes session during which anyone canstand up and say something interesting! -------------- Would you like to speak at our future meetups? You could share about your startup technology stack,your new RubyGem, or your opinions on best practices,so that people can get to know how awesome you are! We also have a 5min section on "5 Random Ruby Tips"that you can volunteer for - I am sure you must havecame across some interesting Ruby nuggets in thelast month right? So don't be shy! Step forward and share your knowledge! Ping Winston @winstonyw / winstonyw@gmail.com,or Guo Xiang @tgx_world / tgx_world@hotmail.com See you all soon! --------------Job Postings-------------- Are you looking for Rubyists? Do you have a job posting?Email us a blurb (< 50 words) + link and we'll put it here. -------------- Thank You, Sponsors! Venue:  


Food and Drinks:
events.location: PayPal, 5 Temasek Blvd, #07-01 Suntec Tower Five, 038985, Singapore

events.name: Book Club: From NAND to Tetris – Assembler & Summary
events.description: Read The Elements of of Computing Systems and/or follow the Coursera course Build a Modern Computer from First Principles: From Nand to Tetris.  This is our last meet up on the course / first half of the book. We will focus on Chapter 6, the week 6 homework and hear each others' general comments on the course/book content.  "I did the coursework because understanding computers is important to me, just like literacy and numeracy, and I made it through. I never worked harder on anything, never been challenged to this degree. But given what I now feel capable of doing, I would certainly do it again. To anyone considering NAND2Tetris, it's a tough journey, but you'll be profoundly changed." Shimon Schocken, the author of the book talks about the course at TED: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iE7YRHxwoDs How Book Club Works 1. Read the chapter before you come to the meetup.2. Find something in the chapter you found interesting and maybe research it a little more.3. At the meetup, we go around the room and each person gets a chance to tell the group about the thing they found interesting.4. Group discussion and banter ensues! Book club is held at Tim & Wei's residence: 244A Tanjong Katong RdSingapore 437032Singapore Doors open at 6:30, meetup starts at 7. Bring snacks and drinks of your choice! Feel free to ask questions in the SingaporeJS gitter room: https://gitter.im/SingaporeJS/discussions Useful Links • NAND to Tetris website: http://www.nand2tetris.org/• Get the book: http://www.amazon.com/Elements-Computing-Systems-Building-Principles/dp/0262640686/• Coursera course: https://www.coursera.org/learn/build-a-computer/
events.location: Tim & Wei's Residence, 244A Tanjong Katong Road, Singapore
